pull.title: net: Split DNS resolving functionality out of net structures
pull.body:
First PR of many in the p2p refactor.

This brings CNetAddr/CSubNet/CService one step closer to being dumb storage structures. By forcing addresses to be resolved elsewhere, the implementation details are free to change. In particular, this is necessary for making the resolves fully async, which is necessary in a model in which the entire connection process is asynchronous.

The DNS seed TODO could be fixed more properly with something like this: https://github.com/theuni/bitcoin/commit/792b0f5da618ea51ecd7b21db633faa6743c1e68 (an ipv6 range would probably make more sense, though), but I'll leave that for another PR.

events.body: meta-comment: Is there an issue open with all the various things to be done for p2p refactor, for a higher-level view? I'd like to review but my knowledge of p2p part of Core is weak. I think a higher-level view may help me review.
@instagibbs good point. I have another RFC PR coming up today, that will be a good place to discuss general scope/goals. I'll begin writing something up.
Concept ACK; utACK apart from one comment
utACK, good to see DNS lookup being decoupled from connecting.

events.message:
net: require lookup functions to specify all arguments

To make it clear where DNS resolves are happening

events.body:
Updated for @sipa's comment.

@instagibbs I didn't manage to get it ready last week as hoped, but a PR that looks similar to https://github.com/theuni/bitcoin/tree/net-refactor12 plus a lengthy explanation is hopefully coming up in the next day or two. That work aims to segregate the p2p functionality from the rest of the code so that it can be replaced in chunks without interfering with other subsystems.

issue.title: net: prerequisites for p2p encapsulation changes
issue.body:
A few boring changes that are required before beginning to encapsulate the p2p code. For reference, https://github.com/theuni/bitcoin/tree/net-refactor12 builds on top of these as well as #7868. The high-level purpose of this work is to encapsulate p2p functionality into a single class rather than scattered globals, so that It may be safely changed without worrying about side-effects.

Regardless of that, I think these are all improvements in their own right. See individual commit messages for more info.

events.message:
net: manually resolve dns seed sources

Note: Some seeds aren't actually returning an IP for their name entries, so
they're being added to addrman with a source of [::].

This commit shouldn't change that behavior, for better or worse.

net: resolve outside of storage structures

Rather than allowing CNetAddr/CService/CSubNet to launch DNS queries, require
that addresses are already resolved.

This greatly simplifies async resolve logic, and makes it harder to
accidentally leak DNS queries.

net: disable resolving from storage structures

CNetAddr/CService/CSubnet can no longer resolve DNS.

events.body:
Addressed @sipa's concern above (I hope). For reference, the following mainnet seeds don't currently resolve their names properly (for me, anyway), so they end up grouped together with sources of [::]:

```
xf2.org
bluematt.me
```

I've confirmed that seed results are added to addrman that way before and after this change. I'll work on fixing that in a follow-up pull-request.

utACK d39f5b425d8fc1bf3b7f33d35625ffd8d7a3cd77

Meta question: I am right to expect that there will be follow-ups that split the Lookup functions in resolving ones and non-resolving ones, and make the CNetAddr constructors only depend in the non-resolving ones?

issue.title: Net: Turn net structures into dumb storage classes
issue.body:
This finishes the work started in #7868. The changed lines count is high, but it's mostly tests.

CNetAddr/CService/CSubNet lose their string constructors, they must now have lookup operations performed externally. This means that functions/classes that depend on them are no longer dependent on any particular lookup mechanism.

From a high level: New resolvers/parsers may now be used for net operations. libbtcnet will replace what remains of netbase with async versions.

issue.title: Net backports
issue.body:
Backports of spelling fixes and changes to netbase that bring us closer to 0.13.0 for it and torcontrol.cpp.

Main API change is to move towards storage-only structures for basic network concepts, and splitting out DNS lookup.  In later changes in Core CNetAddr moves to its own file netaddress.cpp.

bitcoin#7313
bitcoin#7329
bitcoin#7683
bitcoin#7570
bitcoin#7868
+ BU-specific changes

issue.title: Backport Bitcoin PR#7906: net: prerequisites for p2p encapsulation changes
issue.body:
This is backport of Bitcoin PR bitcoin/bitcoin#7906.

It consists of independent simple commits. Each of them can be reviewed separately.

The original PR consists of the following commits.
* bitcoin/bitcoin@52cbce2 net: don't import std namespace
* bitcoin/bitcoin@9faa490 net: remove unused set
* bitcoin/bitcoin@563f375 net: use the exposed GetNodeSignals() rather than g_signals directly
* bitcoin/bitcoin@cca221f net: Drop CNodeRef for AttemptToEvictConnection
* bitcoin/bitcoin@8b8f877 net: make Ban/Unban/ClearBan functionality consistent
* bitcoin/bitcoin@e9ed620 net: No need to export DumpBanlist
* bitcoin/bitcoin@5d5e7a0 net: No need to export ConnectNode

However I didn't include these two commits.
* bitcoin/bitcoin@cca221f net: Drop CNodeRef for AttemptToEvictConnection:
These changes were already included in Dash.
* bitcoin/bitcoin@5d5e7a0 net: No need to export ConnectNode:
Unfortunately, `ConnectNode` is still used in Dash-specific code, so it has to be exported.


The original PR description follows.
---
A few boring changes that are required before beginning to encapsulate the p2p code. For reference, https://github.com/theuni/bitcoin/tree/net-refactor12 builds on top of these as well as bitcoin/bitcoin#7868. The high-level purpose of this work is to encapsulate p2p functionality into a single class rather than scattered globals, so that It may be safely changed without worrying about side-effects.

Regardless of that, I think these are all improvements in their own right. See individual commit messages for more info.

issue.title: Backport Bitcoin PR#7868: net: Split DNS resolving functionality out of net structures
issue.body:
This is backport of Bitcoin PR bitcoin/bitcoin#7868.

This is a PR that is pre-requisite for further backporting bitcoin/bitcoin#8128 that turns net structures into dumb storage classes by removing any resolving from their constructors.

The original PR description follows.
---
First PR of many in the p2p refactor.

This brings CNetAddr/CSubNet/CService one step closer to being dumb storage structures. By forcing addresses to be resolved elsewhere, the implementation details are free to change. In particular, this is necessary for making the resolves fully async, which is necessary in a model in which the entire connection process is asynchronous.

The DNS seed TODO could be fixed more properly with something like this: theuni/bitcoin@792b0f5 (an ipv6 range would probably make more sense, though), but I'll leave that for another PR.

issue.title: Backport Bitcoin PR#8128: Net: Turn net structures into dumb storage classes
issue.body:
This is backport of Bitcoin PR bitcoin/bitcoin#8128.

This PR is followup for PR #1601.

The original PR description follows.
---
This finishes the work started in bitcoin/bitcoin#7868. The changed lines count is high, but it's mostly tests.

CNetAddr/CService/CSubNet lose their string constructors, they must now have lookup operations performed externally. This means that functions/classes that depend on them are no longer dependent on any particular lookup mechanism.

From a high level: New resolvers/parsers may now be used for net operations. libbtcnet will replace what remains of netbase with async versions.

issue.title: [Net] Split DNS resolving functionality out of net structures
issue.body:
Port of https://github.com/bitcoin/bitcoin/pull/7868

This brings CNetAddr/CSubNet/CService one step closer to being dumb storage structures. By forcing addresses to be resolved elsewhere, the implementation details are free to change. In particular, this is necessary for making the resolves fully async, which is necessary in a model in which the entire connection process is asynchronous.

comments.body: If the Lookup fails, shouldn't the InitError below trigger as well?

That's not actually correct. The "source IP" the addresses get assigned to should be stable over multiple runs, as the DNS seed is seen as a potential attacker who is only allowed to modify a certain subset of entries. If the IP changes over time, that protection disappears.
